topRanked.treatmentTitle: Choanolaimus serieporus Leduc & Zhao, 2025, sp. nov.
topRanked.articleTitle: Three new nematode species (Chromadorida: Selachinematidae) from the continental slope of New Zealand
topRanked.summary: Choanolaimus serieporus is a species of roundworm that belongs to the family Selachinematidae. It is characterized by its cylindrical body shape, slightly rounded cephalic region, and large amphidial fovea with 4-5 turns. The species has a short pharynx, a long spicule length, and a gubernaculum consisting of two detached lateral pieces (crurae) tapering distally. It also has three or four precloacal supplements and a tail that is short and rounded.

images.captionText: Fig. 2. Choanolaimus serieporus sp. nov. A. Anterior body region of holotype, ♂ (NIWA 181629). B. Cephalic region of paratype, ♀ (NIWA 181631). C–D. Cephalic region of paratype, ♂ (NIWA 181630). C. Optical cross-section. D. Surface view. E. Posterior body region of paratype, ♀ (NIWA 181631). F. Posterior body region of holotype, ♂ (NIWA 181629). Arrow shows group of dorsosublateral pore complexes. Scale bar: A = 75 µm; B–F = 60 µm.
Fig. 3. Choanolaimus serieporus sp. nov. A. Entire holotype, ♂ (NIWA 181629). B. Entire paratype, ♀ (NIWA 181631). Arrows show groups of dorsosublateral pore complexes. Scale bar = 200 µm.

Fig. 4. Choanolaimus serieporus sp. nov., light micrographs. A–B. Cephalic region of paratype, ♀ (NIWA 181631). A. Surface view. B. Cross-section view. C. Entire paratype, ♂ (NIWA 181630). D. Lateral view of mid-body cuticle of paratype, ♀ (NIWA 181631). E. Proximal portion of posterior testis of paratype, ♂ (NIWA 181630). F. Proximal portion of anterior testis of paratype, ♂ (NIWA 181630). Arrow shows group of dorsosublateral pore complexes. Scale bar: A, B, D = 25 µm; C = 125 µm; E–F = 40 µm.

response.answer: Choanolaimus serieporus sp. nov. can be distinguished from Choanolaimus sparsiporus sp. nov. by several characteristics, including the size of the body (1321-1688 µm vs 1272 µm), the arrangement and number of dorsosublateral pore complexes on each side of the body (4-11 vs 8-11), the shape and structure of the inner labial sensilla, the length and shape of the pharynx, the presence or absence of precloacal supplements, and the type and location of the spicules.
